Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Coupled genetic, geochemical, and physical controls on arsenic mobilization
Award.AbstractNarration: The hazards imposed by arsenic on human health are well recognized and nowhere better exemplified than South/Southeast Asia where the consumption of arsenic contaminated ground water has resulted high incidences of skin disorders and various cancers. Arsenic is usually associated with iron oxide and other minerals in sediments. However, in the absence of oxygen, microbes can carry out iron and arsenic reduction reactions that result in arsenic release from sediments and accumulation in ground water. The contribution of iron vs. arsenate reduction to arsenic release, however, is unclear. Furthermore, our understanding of arsenic fate and transport within soils and sediments is limited by poorly understood biological and geochemical processes occurring within complex ground water flow pathways. Therefore, the overarching goal of this research is to determine how microbial metabolism impacts arsenic transport in sediments and soils. Specifically, researchers will investigate the expression of bacterial genes responsible for iron and arsenic reduction and commensurate biogeochemical processes responsible for controlling the partitioning and mobility of arsenic (along with their spatial distribution) within model systems that simulate the physical complexity of natural soils and sediments. The proposed research integrates biogeochemical and molecular genetic approaches aimed at developing a mechanistic understanding of the impacts of microbes on arsenic contamination of ground water. Because the nature of the arsenic problem is rooted in geomicrobiology, the intellectual merit of the proposed research is the generation of crucial information important to understanding the mechanism(s) leading to arsenic release or retention in sediments. The results will lead to a detailed conceptual model of how genetics and geochemical processes impact microbe-mineral interactions and arsenic fate. The broader impacts of the research will be to integrate research with teaching activities and community outreach by participating in a laboratory research mentorship program (called ACCESS) for community college students of under represented groups and a high school science summer program called COSMOS. Lastly, the collaboration will enhance and promote diversity through intercampus mentorship of minority graduate students at both Stanford and UCSC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Arsenic contamination of drinking water is correlated with increased incidences of cancer among human populations. This project addressed the underlying mechanisms responsible for controlling the movement and toxicity of arsenic in the environment.  Normally arsenic in the form of arsenate is bound to iron oxide minerals.  However, metal-reducing bacteria can dissolve these minerals thereby releasing a more toxic form of arsenic (arsenite) that is readily transported within groundwater.  Under anaerobic conditions, both iron and arsenate reduction may contribute to the release of arsenic from the solid to the aqueous phase (Fig. 1). The contribution of each reductive release mechanism, however, was unclear prior to this project.  Results from the project demonstrated that arsenate reduction in the absence of iron metabolism can cause the release of the more toxic form of arsenic, arsenite, from mineral surfaces.  Figure 2 demonstrates how the metabolic activities of metal reducers can dissolve minerals, specifically ones composed of iron oxide.  The project also investigated the environmental conditions that impact arsenate reduction abilities of metal-reducing bacteria.  Oxygen was found to be a potent inhibitor of arsenate reduction.  Conversely, the activation of these bacteria required the absence of oxygen and the presence of arsenic to “induce” their activities.  The environmental cycling of arsenic is also complicated by iron reduction, which is also known to liberate arsenic into its dissolved form.  Arsenate reducers can further exacerbate the problem by converting it into arsenite.  Results form this project have important implications in developing strategies to control the activities of arsenate reducing bacteria in groundwater.  This is a challenging task given the widespread scale of contamination of many affected groundwater supplies for example as observed in Bangladesh.

As part of the Broader Impacts, the project contributed to enhancing STEM education for high school, community college, undergraduate, and graduate students. For high school students, the NSF project participants taught for a summer program called COSMOS, a 4-week summer residential (students live on campus) STEM academic program of ~165 talented and motivated high school students. For community college students, the NSF-funded researchers mentored students from a program called ACCESS. This is summer research program aimed at providing community college students opportunities to work in faculty research laboratories at UCSC.  Students are usually from disadvantageous backgrounds and/or underrepresented groups from the neighboring community colleges.  For UCSC students, the NSF project supported several undergraduate researchers, two went on to PhD programs.  Several of the NSF-supported UCSC PhD students also contributed to the project for their theses.  Two graduated and went on to postdoctoral positions.  Lastly, the project contributed to the improved performance, skills, and inclusion of members of underrepresented groups.  Finally, most of the students who worked on this project (undergraduate and graduate), participated in various international conferences and presented results from their research.
